DOCNAME: KHAN MANWAR v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;Giovanni Bonello;Lech Garlicki;Mihai Poalelungi;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lived in GPE . He was represented before the ORG by PERSON of ORG , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Mr NORP PERSON of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

The applicant arrived in GPE on DATE with his parents and siblings and was granted Indefinite Leave to Remain . In DATE he returned to GPE to marry and his wife was granted leave to join him in GPE . When he returned to GPE he initially undertook casual work of a manual nature but later suffered a back injury which prevented him from undertaking further permanent work . In DATE he suffered a stroke , which left him partially paralysed .

The applicant and his wife have CARDINAL children living in GPE . The youngest will turn DATE on DATE and the oldest is CARDINAL . The applicant claims that CARDINAL of his children have a disability . The applicant and his wife separated in DATE although the applicant submits that they were later reconciled .

Following the applicant ’s stroke in DATE , he was convicted of CARDINAL offences for which he was sentenced to a total of CARDINAL PERSON imprisonment . These offences included rape , wounding under section CARDINAL of the LAW against LAW , and living off the earnings of a prostitute . On DATE the applicant was convicted by a ORG of possession of a Class A controlled drug with intent to supply . He was sentenced to DATE and CARDINAL months’ imprisonment .

On DATE the applicant was served with a notice of decision to make a deportation order . The Secretary of ORG had considered the effect that deportation was likely to have upon the applicant and his family but concluded that in the light of the seriousness of the applicant ’s criminal offence , his removal was necessary in a NORP society for the prevention of disorder and crime and for the protection of health and morals .
The applicant ’s appeal against this decision was dismissed on DATE by an Immigration Judge .

In particular , the Immigration Judge noted that the applicant continued to deny culpability for the offence and did not demonstrate any remorse for it . During DATE his disregard of the law had been blatant and frequent and the probation officer considered that the risk of re - offending was high .

In relation to the applicant ’s medical condition , the judge accepted that he had some residual physical disability arising from a stroke in DATE . In particular , he had a limp and could not walk without the assistance of a stick . He also accepted that the applicant suffered from asthma and epilepsy , but noted that no medical evidence had been submitted to substantiate the level of the applicant ’s claimed disabilities . He concluded that the applicant had exaggerated the extent of his disability , and found that his medical needs could be met in GPE .

Moreover , the judge was not satisfied that the applicant no longer had connections in GPE . In relation to the applicant ’s family life in GPE , he did not accept that the applicant and his wife had become reconciled . He noted that following his release from prison , the applicant lived in a different town from his wife . Although he visited his wife and children on alternatives DATE , he did not stay in his wife ’s home during these visits .

On DATE a deportation order was signed . On DATE the applicant was detained and removal directions were set for CARDINAL DATE . The applicant sought permission to apply for judicial review . ORG deferred the removal directions pending the determination of the judicial review proceedings .

On DATE ORG refused the application for permission to apply for judicial review . The applicant renewed his application for permission to an oral hearing , which took place on DATE . Permission to apply for judicial review was again refused by ORG . The applicant made further representations to the Secretary of ORG , which were rejected as containing no new information .
The applicant was deported to GPE on CARDINAL DATE .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) of LAW DATE ( as amended by ORG ) provides that a person who is not a NORP citizen shall be liable to deportation from GPE if the Secretary of ORG for ORG deems his deportation to be conducive to the public good . Sections CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL of the Nationality , Immigration and Asylum Act DATE provide for a right of appeal against this decision on the grounds , inter alia , that the decision is incompatible with the Convention .

Section CARDINAL of LAW DATE provides that , in determining any question that arises in connection with a Convention right , courts and tribunals must take into account any case - law from this ORG so far as , in the opinion of the court or tribunal , it is relevant to the proceedings in which that question has arisen .

The Rules relating to the revocation of a deportation order are contained in paragraphs LAW of ORG CARDINAL ( as amended ) , supplemented by LAW ( “ IDIs ” ) . There is no specific period after which revocation will be appropriate although ORG to LAW of the IDIs gives broad guidelines on the length of time deportation orders should remain in force after removal . Cases which will normally be appropriate for revocation DATE after deportation include those of overstayers and persons who failed to observe a condition attached to their leave , persons who obtained leave by deception , and family members deported under LAW ) of LAW DATE . With regard to criminal conviction cases , the normal course of action will be to grant an application for revocation where the decision to deport was founded on a criminal conviction which is now “ spent ” under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the Rehabilitation of Offenders Act DATE . Paragraph CARDINAL of the Rules , however , indicates that in the case of an applicant with a serious criminal record continued exclusion for a long term of years will normally be the proper course . This is expanded on in GPE A to LAW of the IDIs , which indicates that revocation would not normally be appropriate until DATE after departure for those convicted of serious offences such as violence against the person , sexual offences , burglary , robbery or theft , and other offences such as forgery and drug trafficking .
